column1: A parliament is a type of legislature.The most famous parliament is probably the one in the United Kingdom
column2: which is sometimes called the "Mother of all Parliaments". The word "parliament" comes from the French word parler
column6: so it is the oldest legislature in the world still existing. However
column7: the Althing did not function as a legislature for four centuries
column8: and its role as a primary legislature is modern.The Parliament of the United Kingdom is split into three separate parts
column9: the House of Commons (the lower house)
column10: the lords (the upper house) and the Monarch. Most legislative power is concentrated in the House of Commons. It is made up of 650 Members of Parliament (MPs). These people are elected by the people of the United Kingdom to represent them in the House of Commons. The leader of the political party who commands a majority of MPs is usually made the Prime Minister
column11: but not the Head of State
column12: a position reserved for the Sovereign.
